docs.lead_paragraph: Another aspect of health care is coming up for some needed reform. The chief executive of the King's Fund, an influential British health charity and research organization, says it is high time to abolish the word ''patient.'' Derived from the Latin ''patior,'' or ''I suffer,'' ''the word indicates immediately the unequal nature'' of the relationship between the patient and the doctor,'' the executive, Rabbi Julia Neuberger, wrote in the June 26 issue of The British Medical Journal.
docs.abstract: Essay by Dr Abigail Zuger says article in The British Medical Journal suggests that word 'patient' should be changed because it implies timid, passive, horizontal creature; notes that 'doctors' have become 'health professionals'; says real issue to contemplate is reality of modern health care; notes that whatever name people answer to, care givers and care receivers are explorers, fellow adventurers, worried pilgrims all; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Defense Department's new guidelines on the ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy may reduce some of the worse abuses against homosexuals in the military. But it does not cure the fundamental injustice of a policy that discriminates against homosexuals by forcing them to hide their sexual orientation and by punishing the truthful with expulsion. Last year, the department issued a report showing that the number of gay soldiers being forced out of the military had risen sharply since adoption of the ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy in 1994. That policy was a compromise between the White House, which wanted to end all discrimination against homosexuals, and opponents in the Senate and the military who wanted to continue the longstanding ban on homosexuals in the armed forces. Under the compromise, openly gay people are still barred from the armed services. But they are allowed to serve if they do not talk openly about their sexual orientation, and commanders are barred from asking troops if they are gay.
docs.abstract: Editorial says Defense Dept's new guidelines on 'don't ask, don't tell' policy may reduce some of worse abuses against homosexuals in military, but does not cure fundamental injustice of policy that discriminates against gays by forcing them to hide their sexual orientation and by punishing truthful with expulsion (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Josephine Richards was still on the delivery table when she learned that her newborn son, David, had Down syndrome. Her first reaction was not sadness, although she saw her husband crying. It was, she said, ''I have to do something.'' ''I was really in a twilight zone,'' Ms. Richards said. ''There were times I would feel happy, and then I would say, ''Oh, my God, what's going to happen to this baby, and how am I ever going to do this?''

headline.main: Program for Disabled Children Ends Abruptly

docs.abstract: Article on Early Intervention Program of Monmouth and Ocean Counties Inc, federally financed service that offered free evaluation and therapy for disabled and developmentally delayed children younger than 3, which closed without notice on August 11; Josephine Richards, whose son has Down syndrome, comments; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Leaders of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers endorsed a contract proposal from the Boeing company yesterday, greatly reducing the chances that its 44,000 members will strike on Thursday. After 12 days of intense negotiations at a hotel outside Seattle, Boeing submitted its final contract offer to the machinists early yesterday, offering several concessions and a wage increase of nearly 16 percent over three years.

headline.main: Union Leaders Say They Support Boeing's Final Contract Offer

docs.abstract: Leaders of International Assn of Machinists and Aerospace Workers endorse contract proposal from Boeing Co, greatly reducing chances that its 44,000 members will strike; Boeing submits its final contract offer to machinists, offering several concessions and wage increase of nearly 16 percent over three years (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: TOWARD the end of every year, millions of Americans go on medical shopping sprees. They get their teeth cleaned and their eyes checked. They buy designer eyeglasses, orthopedic shoes and long-term supplies of birth-control pills. Some even make extra appointments with their analysts. These people are taking advantage of a tax break called flexible spending accounts that hardly anyone believes is good public policy. While the Government's goal is to hold down medical costs, this part of the tax law encourages extra medical spending.

headline.main: When Laws Shoot Themselves in the Foot

docs.abstract: David E Rosenbaum article on Federal laws, designed with best of intent, that have turned out to work at cross-purposes with Government policy; cites three such laws, dealing with flexible spending accounts, flood insurance and consumer complaints (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''The Great American Stock Selloff,'' (Investing, Aug. 8): Investor angst over President Clinton's proposed Medicare drug plan shows how superficial analysis can result in missed opportunity.
docs.abstract: Cambridge Pharma Consultancy managing consultant Dr Kenneth LaPensee and president Dr Joseph Zammit-Lucia letter on August 8 article holds wise investors will view Pres Clinton's proposed Medicare drug plan as opportunity
